alt_statements.statement: I think the Electoral College should be changed so that every person’s vote across the whole country counts the same, kind of like how everyone in a class vote should matter equally. It feels more fair if the president is chosen by whoever gets the most votes from all the people, not just by how states are set up. Since we learn in church and at home about fairness and treating people equally, I think our voting system should match that too.

As a Democrat who cares a lot about fairness and representation, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether you’re in Delaware or a swing state. It doesn’t sit right with me that someone can win the presidency while losing the popular vote, and it feels like my voice is discounted just because of where I live. A direct popular vote would push candidates to campaign everywhere and speak to the whole country, not just a handful of states.

I don’t really get all the details of the Electoral College, but it seems a little weird that the person with the most votes might not become president. I think it would be more fair if every vote from every person counted the same, no matter what state they live in, so the winner is just whoever gets the most votes in the whole country.

As someone who values fairness and clear rules, I think we should seriously consider moving toward a national popular vote, or at least reforming the Electoral College so that electoral votes are awarded proportionally rather than winner-take-all. It doesn’t sit right with me that a candidate can win the presidency without winning the most votes, and as a moderate voter in a family-focused, middle-of-the-country life, I’d like every individual vote—whether in Nebraska or New York—to count equally.

Given how much time I spend examining fine print and weighing evidence, the Electoral College just looks like an outdated mechanism that distorts the actual will of voters and over-privileges a handful of swing states. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, or at minimum reforms like ranked-choice voting and proportional allocation of electors so that every ballot—whether it’s cast in New Mexico or New York—has the same weight in choosing the president.

Given our constitutional framework and the size and diversity of this country, I think we should keep the Electoral College but modernize it rather than scrap it. I’d support reforms like requiring states to allocate their electors proportionally or by congressional district instead of winner-take-all, and tightening up rules around faithless electors. That approach preserves the balance between states and the popular will, while making elections feel fairer and reducing the sense that a few swing states decide everything.

Given my belief in our constitutional framework and concern for stability, I don’t think we should abolish the Electoral College, but I do think it could be updated. I’d support reforms like requiring states to allocate electors proportionally or by congressional district, so rural and small-state voters like many of us in Tennessee still have a meaningful voice, while elections better reflect the popular will.

Como alguien que vino de Nicaragua y cree profundamente en la justicia social, pienso que el Colegio Electoral ya no representa bien la voluntad popular y debería ser reemplazado por la elección directa del presidente por voto popular nacional. En mi trabajo en telecomunicaciones, veo cómo la tecnología hace posible contar con precisión millones de votos, así que no hay razón democrática para que el voto de una persona valga más que el de otra según el estado donde viva. Una reforma hacia voto popular, quizás con una segunda vuelta si nadie supera cierto porcentaje, haría que cada campaña tuviera que hablarle a todos, incluyendo a comunidades inmigrantes y minorías, no solo a unos pocos “swing states”.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that everyone’s vote counts the same no matter what state they live in, kind of like when we vote for class president and the person with the most votes wins. It feels more fair if every person’s vote is added up together across the whole country, instead of some states mattering more than others. As a kid, that teaches me that everyone’s voice is equal, which is something my parents and my church say is really important.

Given how interconnected and informed our country is today, I believe it’s time to replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether you’re in Milwaukee or Missoula. As a civics-minded teacher and a Democrat, I see firsthand how the current system discourages participation in “safe” states and sidelines many voices, which runs against both my sense of fairness and my belief in broad, inclusive democracy.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count equally no matter what state they live in. It feels wrong that someone can win the presidency while losing the popular vote, and it makes a lot of people—especially young voters like me—feel like their voices don’t matter. A popular vote system would push candidates to pay attention to all communities, not just a few swing states, and that seems more fair and democratic.

The Electoral College should be preserved because it protects the voice of smaller and less populated states, prevents candidates from only focusing on big coastal cities, and reinforces the federal nature of our system. That said, I’d support some targeted reforms—like tightening rules on electors so they must vote according to their state’s results, and improving transparency in how votes are counted—to maintain public trust without throwing out a system that has provided stability for over two centuries.

I support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote, so every person’s ballot carries equal weight no matter what state they live in. As someone who analyzes systems for a living, I see the current structure as inefficient, distortionary, and too vulnerable to outcomes that don’t reflect the will of the majority. A direct popular vote, backed by strong national voting standards and protections, would be a more democratic, transparent, and modern way to elect a president.

Como alguien que valora las tradiciones pero también la justicia, pienso que el Colegio Electoral necesita algunas reformas, pero no eliminarlo por completo. Me preocupa que solo las grandes ciudades decidan por todo el país, así que entiendo la idea de proteger a los estados más pequeños. Sin embargo, creo que sería más justo que los votos electorales se repartan de manera proporcional al voto popular de cada estado, para que la voz de todos cuente mejor. Así se mantiene la estructura tradicional, pero se acerca más a la voluntad real del pueblo.

I think the Electoral College should be preserved, because it protects the influence of smaller and less populated states so that big cities don’t completely control national elections. That said, I’d be open to some modest reforms—like making the process more transparent or tightening rules around how electors are chosen—so people can trust the system more without throwing out a structure that’s worked for our country for a long time.

I’m cautious about sweeping changes to the Electoral College, because it forces candidates to pay attention to different regions and not just the biggest cities, and as an immigrant and a small business employee, I don’t want politics decided only by coastal population centers. That said, I’d support reforms that make the system more transparent and responsive—like allocating electoral votes by congressional district or using ranked-choice voting within states—so people feel their votes matter without throwing out a structure that has helped keep the country stable.

At my age, having watched a lot of elections come and go, I still believe the Electoral College plays an important role in forcing candidates to pay attention to the whole country, not just the big coastal cities. That said, I’d be open to reforms like allocating electors by congressional district or using ranked-choice voting within states, so people feel their vote matters more without scrapping the system entirely. I worry that a straight national popular vote would weaken the voice of smaller states and rural communities that already feel overlooked.

As someone who values both tradition and fairness, I believe we should keep the Electoral College but make modest reforms to improve representation and trust. I would support changes like allocating electoral votes by congressional district or requiring states to follow clearer, uniform rules for elections and recounts, so every lawful vote is respected while still preserving the balance between large and small states that our founders intended.

I don’t see much good in throwing out the Electoral College entirely; this country’s built on a balance between the states, not just big cities and the coasts. I’d be open to some tweaks, like making states award their electors by congressional district or tightening up how votes are counted and verified, but I still want the system to protect smaller, rural states like mine from being steamrolled.

I don’t know every detail about how the Electoral College works, but it feels weird that someone can win the presidency without getting the most votes from people. I think it would be more fair if the popular vote decided the winner, since every person’s vote would count the same no matter what state they live in. Maybe we could gradually move toward that by having states split their electoral votes based on their own popular votes, instead of winner-take-all.

I’ve always believed the Electoral College made sense when the country was younger and more rural, but it feels out of step with how people think about fairness today. I’d like to see a system where the popular vote matters more directly—maybe keeping states involved but using something like ranked-choice or proportional allocation of electors so every vote counts more evenly. That way we still respect the balance between big and small states, but we don’t end up with presidents who lose the popular vote.

I think the Electoral College needs some updating, but I’m not sold on scrapping it entirely. A system where states award their electoral votes proportionally, or follow the popular vote within each congressional district, might keep smaller and rural states like mine from getting steamrolled while still making every vote feel like it counts. What I don’t want is a setup where only big cities and coastal states decide everything, but I do think people should feel their individual vote matters more than it does now.

Como alguien que emigró de México, se hizo ciudadana, y vota en cada elección, me cuesta aceptar que la persona con más votos en todo el país pueda perder por culpa del Colegio Electoral. Creo que deberíamos movernos hacia una elección presidencial por voto popular nacional, donde cada voto cuente igual, sin importar en qué estado vivas. Eso reflejaría mejor la voluntad del pueblo y motivaría a más participación, especialmente entre comunidades como la mía que ya se sienten ignoradas.

I think it’s time to move to a national popular vote, because every person’s ballot should count the same no matter what state they’re in, especially for Black voters in states that get ignored once they’re labeled “safe.” The Electoral College feels like an outdated compromise that lets a minority of voters overrule the majority, which doesn’t sit right with my belief in fairness and real democracy. I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact or a constitutional amendment to elect the president directly, so candidates have to speak to everyone, not just a handful of swing states.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, maybe with some small adjustments to how states award their electors. It forces candidates to pay attention to the whole country, not just big cities on the coasts, and that matters to folks in places like West Virginia. If anything, I’d prefer reforms that make voter ID and election security stronger rather than scrapping the system we’ve had for so long.

I don’t think we should get rid of the Electoral College, but I do think it could use some reforms so people feel their vote actually counts. Maybe we could move to something like proportional allocation of electors within each state, so rural and small-town voices like mine don’t get drowned out, but individual votes matter more. The system was set up to protect smaller states, and I still think that’s important, but there’s room to make it fairer and more transparent.

As someone who works in information security and believes in systems that are transparent, resilient, and fair, I think the Electoral College needs serious reform. I’d prefer a national popular vote, or at least something like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, so that every ballot is weighed equally no matter what state you live in. The current winner-take-all setup in most states distorts representation, discourages turnout in “safe” states, and doesn’t reflect the democratic values I care about as a liberal Democrat.

At my age, I tend to think the Electoral College has generally served the country well by forcing candidates to appeal to a broad range of states and regions, not just the big cities and the coasts. That said, I could support some modest reforms—like allocating electors by congressional district, or standardizing state rules—to make the process a bit fairer and more transparent without throwing out a system that helps preserve the voice of smaller and more rural states.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but with some careful improvements rather than throwing it out entirely. It helps make sure smaller and more rural states like mine aren’t totally drowned out by big cities, but I’d be open to reforms like tightening up how electors are chosen or encouraging states to use a fairer system for awarding their votes. I don’t want a straight popular vote where a few large states decide everything, but I do think we should make the process more transparent and trustworthy so people have more confidence in the results.

I don’t really understand all the rules, but it seems fair if every person’s vote counts the same, no matter where they live. My family talks about how a lot of Native people don’t feel heard, so I think changing the Electoral College so that the person with the most votes wins would help everyone’s voice matter more.

As someone who believes deeply in community and every person’s voice mattering, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that the candidate with the most votes actually wins. It doesn’t sit right with me that some people’s votes effectively count more depending on where they live, especially when so many already feel unheard. A simple, direct vote would better reflect the will of the people and encourage candidates to listen to all communities, not just the so-called “swing states.”

At my age, I’ve seen the country go through a lot, and I still believe the Electoral College plays an important role in making sure smaller and more rural states, like the Georgia I grew up in, aren’t drowned out by the big cities. I don’t support scrapping it for a straight popular vote, but I could accept sensible reforms that make the process more transparent and ensure electors follow the will of their state’s voters. Keeping a balance between the voice of the people and the voice of the states seems important to preserving the stability and fairness of our system.

I think the Electoral College should be reformed into something closer to a national popular vote, because every person’s ballot ought to matter equally no matter what state they live in. At the same time, I’d support a system that still encourages candidates to pay attention to smaller and more rural states, maybe through ranked-choice voting or some regional structure, so our politics doesn’t get totally dominated by just a few big cities.

As someone who works with data and evidence every day, I find the Electoral College increasingly hard to justify in a modern, diverse democracy. I would favor replacing it with a national popular vote, ensuring that every ballot carries equal weight regardless of state lines, coupled with strong protections for voting rights and access. If a full replacement is politically unattainable, I’d at least support reforms like proportional allocation of electors or ranked-choice voting at the state level to better reflect the actual preferences of voters. A system that so directly shapes national policy should be transparent, representative, and resistant to partisan manipulation.

As someone who believes every voice should matter equally, I think we should replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote so the candidate who gets the most votes actually wins the presidency. Growing up in Washington and caring about the world my baby will inherit, it bothers me that some votes count more just because of where people live, and that candidates can basically ignore certain states. A system where every vote is valued the same would push politicians to listen to communities like mine—workers, parents, and people of color—no matter what state we’re in.

I don’t really understand big voting things yet, but I think everyone’s vote should count the same, no matter where they live. Maybe instead of the Electoral College, they could just add up all the people’s votes and whoever gets the most wins, like when we vote in class for a game. That feels more fair and easier to explain to kids like me.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because it feels unfair that some people’s votes matter more just because of where they live. If every vote counted the same, candidates would have to care about everyone, not just a few “swing states.” That seems more in line with social justice and what we’re taught in school about democracy and equality.

As someone who believes in fairness and every voice counting equally, I think we should move toward a national popular vote to replace the Electoral College. It troubles me that a candidate can win the presidency without winning the most votes, and that some states get so much more attention than others while many voters feel ignored. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and encourage candidates to speak to all Americans, not just those in a handful of swing states.

I don’t support scrapping the Electoral College, because it forces presidential candidates to build broad, nationwide coalitions instead of just chasing votes in a few big cities and coastal states. That said, I’d be open to reforms like allocating electors by congressional district or tightening procedures to make vote counting and certification more transparent and secure.

At my age, I’ve seen enough elections to feel that every vote should count as equally as possible, no matter where you live. I’d like to see the Electoral College either significantly reformed—perhaps by allocating electors proportionally within each state—or replaced with a straightforward popular vote, so the candidate with the most votes actually wins. That seems fair, easier for people to understand, and more in keeping with the basic civics I used to teach my students.

I don’t totally get how the Electoral College works, but it seems weird that the person with the most votes doesn’t always win. I think it would be more fair if everyone’s vote counted the same no matter what state they live in, kind of like how every kid in my class gets one vote when we pick something. That way, the president would be the person that the most people in the whole country actually chose.

As a naturalized citizen who takes democratic participation seriously, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot, including those from immigrant-heavy states like mine, counts equally. In my work, accuracy and fairness are non‑negotiable; our elections should follow the same standard instead of letting a handful of swing states decide outcomes. A well-designed popular vote system, with strong protections for voting rights and election security, would better reflect the will of the people and strengthen trust in our democracy.

I don’t know all the details about the Electoral College, but it seems weird that someone can win the presidency without getting the most votes from the people. I think it would be more fair if every vote counted the same, no matter what state you live in, because my family came here believing that everyone’s voice should matter. Maybe they could at least change the system so states’ votes match the popular vote better, so people don’t feel like their vote doesn’t count.

I don’t think we should scrap the Electoral College, but I do think we can tighten it up so folks trust it more. I’d be open to reforms like making states allocate electors by congressional district or requiring stronger safeguards against fraud, but I’m against a straight national popular vote that would let big coastal cities decide everything. The Electoral College forces candidates to pay attention to different parts of the country, including places like Alabama, and that balance is worth protecting.

As a naturalized citizen and a physician who sees daily how every person’s life has equal value, I believe our presidential elections should more fully reflect the principle of “one person, one vote.” I would replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote, or at least adopt reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, so that every ballot—whether cast in California or Wyoming—carries the same weight. Such a system would better honor both my Catholic belief in the equal dignity of each person and my humanistic conviction that our institutions should reflect the collective will of the people as directly as possible.

As someone who believes in fairness and having every voice count equally, I think we should move toward a national popular vote to replace the Electoral College. It doesn’t sit right with me that a candidate can win the presidency while losing the popular vote, especially when so many people are working hard, raising families, and still making the effort to participate in our democracy. A popular vote would make every ballot—from big cities to small Montana towns like where I’m from—matter the same, and that feels more in line with American values.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that the person who gets the most votes from all Americans actually becomes president, because that feels more fair and easier to understand. Coming from the Philippines where people vote directly, it’s weird to me that someone in the U.S. can win the presidency without the most votes, and it seems like it makes some people’s voices count less depending on where they live.

As someone who chose to become an American and drives people from every background around the city, I think the president should be elected by a straightforward national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The Electoral College makes some votes effectively worth more than others and leads campaigns to ignore whole regions, which feels undemocratic to me. If abolishing it entirely isn’t feasible right away, I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact or proportional allocation of electors as steps toward a more direct and representative system.

I’d like to see the Electoral College reformed so that every person’s vote counts more equally—maybe through a national popular vote or by awarding electoral votes proportionally instead of winner-take-all. As someone who works hard, supports a family, and believes in individual freedom, it doesn’t sit right with me that a candidate can win the presidency without winning the most votes nationwide.

As a conservative and a Christian, I believe the Electoral College is an important safeguard that protects the voice of smaller states like New Mexico and keeps our elections from being dominated by a few big coastal cities. I’m open to modest reforms that improve transparency and discourage attempts to manipulate the system, but I oppose getting rid of the Electoral College or moving to a pure national popular vote, which I think would further divide the country and weaken our federal system.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because it feels more fair that every single person’s vote counts the same no matter what state they live in. Growing up in California, it sometimes feels like our votes are already decided, and that makes people my age less interested in politics. If we really care about democracy and everyone having a voice—like we say we do in school and at church—then the system should match that by directly reflecting what most voters want.

As a conservative and a Republican, I believe the Electoral College remains an important safeguard that ensures smaller and less populous states still have a meaningful voice, preventing our elections from being dominated solely by a few major urban areas. That said, I’d support targeted reforms—like standardizing how states allocate electors or increasing transparency in the process—so long as they preserve federalism and the balance between state and national interests that the Founders intended.

As someone who believes in democracy and in the power of people’s voices—just like music connects crowds—I think the Electoral College needs to be replaced with a national popular vote. Every vote should carry the same weight, whether you’re in Connecticut or a small town in the Midwest, so politicians have to speak to everyone, not just “swing states.” At the very least, we should move to a system that awards electoral votes proportionally by state, so the final result better reflects the will of the people.

Given my background as a naturalized citizen from Vietnam, I find it troubling that the Electoral College can allow someone to win the presidency without winning the popular vote, which feels fundamentally at odds with the idea of “one person, one vote.” I would support replacing it with a national popular vote, or at least reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact and ranked-choice voting, so that every ballot—whether from a big city or a rural town—counts equally and encourages candidates to represent the whole country, not just a handful of swing states.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but it could use some fine-tuning rather than being thrown out. It forces candidates to care about more than just the big cities and coasts, which protects states like mine from being ignored, but I’d support reforms like allocating electors by congressional district or tightening rules around faithless electors. That way we keep the balance between the states and the people, while making the system a bit fairer and more accountable.

At my age, having taught young people to think critically about democracy, I’ve come to believe the Electoral College is outdated and should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot carries equal weight, no matter the state. Watching elections where the winner of the popular vote loses the presidency has been disheartening and, frankly, undermines faith in the system. A direct popular vote, with safeguards for voting rights and access, would better reflect the will of the people and align with the democratic ideals I spent my career teaching.

As a Black Jamaican American and a nurse who believes deeply in compassion and fairness, I think we should move toward a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts equally, no matter where they live. The Electoral College gives disproportionate power to a few swing states and can ignore the voices of communities like mine, especially in larger states and urban areas. At the very least, we should reform it with measures like proportional allocation of electoral votes so that election outcomes more accurately reflect the will of the people.

Given our constitutional system and the importance of federalism, I think the Electoral College should be preserved, not abolished. That said, I’d support reforms like more consistent state rules on how electors are chosen and greater transparency, so people trust that their votes are fairly translated into electoral outcomes. The current system protects smaller and rural states like Nebraska from being ignored by big urban centers, and that balance is important for keeping the country united.

I don’t totally get all the complicated parts of the Electoral College, but it seems kind of unfair that someone can win the most votes in the whole country and still lose the election. I think it would be better if every person’s vote counted the same no matter what state they live in, so the winner is whoever gets the most votes from all the people. Maybe grown-ups could change the rules so smaller states still get heard, but not in a way that makes people feel like their vote doesn’t really matter.

I think the person who becomes president should be the one that the most people in the whole country vote for, like when we count all the points to see who really won a game. The Electoral College seems confusing, and it feels unfair that someone can win even if more people wanted someone else. I like things to be simple and honest, so I’d rather we just count every vote the same, no matter what state you live in.

Given how much our work in software depends on clean, transparent systems, the Electoral College has always struck me as an outdated abstraction layer that obscures the will of the voters. I’d support moving to a national popular vote—with strong, uniform standards for ballot access, security, and auditing—so that every vote is weighted equally, whether you’re in Pennsylvania or Wyoming. At the very least, reforms like proportional allocation of electors or the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact are sensible interim steps toward a more democratic, modern election system.

Coming from Spain, where the head of government is chosen through parliamentary elections rather than something like the U.S. Electoral College, I find it strange that a candidate can win fewer popular votes but still become president. I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, so every vote counts equally regardless of state, which feels more democratic and consistent with my left-leaning values. A direct popular vote would also likely encourage higher participation and make young, diverse, and urban voices like mine matter more in the outcome.

At my age, I’ve seen enough elections to believe it’s time we moved to a system where the person with the most votes nationwide actually wins—one person, one vote. The Electoral College feels outdated and can make some voters’ voices, especially in safe states like mine, matter less than others. I’d support either abolishing it in favor of a national popular vote or at least reforming it so electoral votes are awarded proportionally, not winner-take-all. That would better reflect the will of the people and strengthen our democracy.

I think the president should be picked by whoever gets the most votes from all the people, because that feels the most fair, like when we vote for class captain and whoever gets the most wins. The Electoral College seems confusing and makes it feel like some people’s votes count more just because of where they live, and that doesn’t seem right or honest.

As someone who believes deeply in teaching kids that every voice matters, I think we should move toward a national popular vote to replace the Electoral College so that every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system makes some states feel ignored, and that’s not the kind of civics lesson I want my children—or the kids at my center—to grow up with. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and encourage broader participation in our democracy.

I don’t totally get all the rules about the Electoral College, but I think it would be more fair if everyone’s vote counted the same, no matter what state they live in. Grown-ups always tell me that every person matters to God, so I think our voting should show that too, maybe with something like just adding up all the votes in the whole country.

As someone who believes in making every vote count equally, I think we should move toward a national popular vote to replace the Electoral College. It feels undemocratic that a handful of swing states have so much more influence than voters in places like Michigan, and that candidates can win the presidency without winning the most votes. At the very least, we should adopt reforms like proportional allocation of electors or the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact as a step toward a fairer, more representative system.

At my age, I’ve seen enough elections to believe the Electoral College no longer reflects the will of the people the way it should. I’d prefer a national popular vote where every vote counts the same, whether you live in New Jersey or a small rural state, so candidates have to speak to everyone, not just a handful of “swing” states. If we can’t abolish it outright, then at least states should allocate their electors proportionally instead of winner-take-all, to better match how people actually vote.

As a progressive and a software developer who thinks a lot about systems, I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot is weighted equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system encourages candidates to focus on a handful of swing states while sidelining diverse communities like mine, and that’s fundamentally out of step with democratic values. At minimum, I’d support reforms such as the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact or proportional allocation of electors as steps toward a fairer, more representative system.

I think the Electoral College still serves a purpose, because it keeps big cities from totally drowning out folks in smaller states like mine. That said, I’d support reforms that make the system more fair, like using the Maine and Nebraska model where electoral votes are split by congressional district instead of winner-take-all. That would keep the balance between states while making more people feel like their vote actually matters.

Given my work supporting vulnerable families and my belief in social justice, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot carries equal weight, no matter their state. The current system makes some votes effectively count more than others and encourages candidates to focus on a few swing states, which feels fundamentally unfair in a democracy. As someone who cares about community voice and representation, I want a system where the president is chosen directly by the people, majority to majority, with strong protections for voting rights and access in every community.

As a teacher and a mom, I want my kids to grow up in a country where every vote truly counts the same, no matter what state you live in. I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote, or at least reformed so that electoral votes are awarded proportionally instead of winner-take-all. That would make candidates pay attention to all communities—including Latino and working families like mine—instead of just a handful of swing states.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but reformed so it better reflects voters in each state—like adopting a proportional allocation of electors instead of winner-take-all. The current system forces candidates to pay attention to smaller and more rural states like the one I live in, which I see as important for protecting against pure big-city rule. At the same time, I want my students to feel their individual votes matter, and a proportional approach might make outcomes feel fairer without abandoning the federalist structure the founders intended.

As someone who teaches civics to middle schoolers, I find it hard to justify an Electoral College system where a handful of swing states end up with outsized influence, while many of my students’ future votes could feel like they “don’t count” if they live in a safe state. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote or at least adopting reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, so that every vote is weighed equally and candidates have to appeal to people across the whole country, not just in a few key regions.

As someone who believes deeply in fairness and works every day in a diverse campus community, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot truly counts the same, whether it’s cast in Iowa or California. The current system makes many voters feel invisible and distorts candidates’ priorities toward a handful of swing states. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people, encourage broader participation, and align our presidential elections with the democratic values we teach our students.

As someone who believes in hard work and fairness, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s vote counts equally, no matter what state they live in. Right now, candidates focus mostly on a few swing states, and that leaves a lot of communities like mine feeling ignored, even though we’re working, paying taxes, and raising families. A popular vote system would push politicians to pay attention to all people—especially working-class and minority communities—because every single vote would matter the same.

As a voter, a mom, and someone who deals with numbers for a living, I think the Electoral College is outdated and undermines the basic democratic idea that every vote should count equally. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, or at least reforms like proportional allocation of electors, so that candidates have to earn support from people in every state, not just a handful of swing states.

I think the Electoral College should mostly stay, because it protects smaller and rural states like mine from being totally ignored by big cities on the coasts. That said, I’d be open to states using a system like Maine and Nebraska where electoral votes are split by congressional district, so folks feel like their vote matters even if their state leans heavily one way.

My mom tells me that when people vote for president, sometimes the one with more people liking him still doesn’t win because of something called the Electoral College, and that feels a little unfair to me. I think it would be better if every person’s vote just counted the same no matter where they live, like when we all get one turn in a game and it really counts. Maybe grown-ups could change the rules so the person who gets the most votes from all the people in the whole country is the one who wins.

I don't really understand the Electoral College very much, but I think it would be fair if the person who gets the most votes becomes president. That seems like when we vote in class for a game and whoever gets the most hands raised wins. Maybe grown-ups could change the rules so everyone's vote counts the same, no matter what state they live in.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved, but updated so that it better reflects the will of the people while still protecting the voice of smaller states. A system where each state awards its electors proportionally based on the popular vote, instead of winner-take-all, could strike a better balance between honoring our federalist structure and making sure every vote counts more fairly.

As someone serving in the armed forces, I respect the Constitution and the stability it’s provided, so I’m cautious about throwing out the Electoral College entirely. That said, I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact or proportional allocation of electors within states, so that each vote counts more evenly without completely abandoning the federal structure. This kind of change would keep smaller states and diverse regions relevant while making outcomes feel fairer to ordinary voters and military families stationed all over the country.

As a Democrat and a data-oriented researcher, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, so that every ballot carries equal weight regardless of state. The current system distorts campaigning toward a handful of swing states and can produce outcomes that diverge from the will of the majority, which undermines democratic legitimacy. A direct popular vote, possibly with ranked-choice voting to ensure majority support for the winner, would better align with both basic fairness and empirical evidence on representative systems.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts equally, whether you’re in Florida like me or some small swing state. It feels wrong that someone can win the presidency while losing the popular vote, and it makes a lot of people feel like their voices don’t matter. A direct popular vote would push candidates to focus on the whole country, not just a handful of swing states, and that lines up better with democratic values I care about.

I don’t think the Electoral College should be scrapped, but I do believe it could use some reforms to make people feel their vote counts more. Maybe we could keep the basic structure, but adopt a system like Maine and Nebraska where electoral votes are split by congressional district, so rural and smaller states like Mississippi don’t get drowned out, while still better reflecting the popular will.

As a Catholic and a Democrat who cares deeply about fairness and the common good, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts equally, no matter where they live. Right now, candidates focus on a handful of swing states and ignore so many voices, which doesn’t sit right with my sense of justice or my belief in the dignity of every person. I’d support reforms that either abolish the Electoral College or bind it more tightly to the national popular vote, so the winner truly reflects the will of the majority.

As someone who’s spent her career thinking about systems and impacts, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter where you live. The current system makes some states matter far more than others and discourages participation, which undermines both fairness and democracy. A well-designed popular vote system—with strong national voting standards, protections against voter suppression, and secure election administration—would better reflect the will of the people.

Given how much I work with systems and efficiency, the Electoral College feels like a legacy architecture that no longer scales for a modern democracy. I’d support moving to a national popular vote—ideally with ranked-choice voting—so that every ballot is weighted equally and candidates have to campaign everywhere, not just in swing states. That kind of reform would align better with democratic principles while leveraging data and technology to administer elections securely and transparently.

As someone who came here from Mexico and works hard running my own construction business, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, so every person’s ballot carries the same weight no matter what state they live in. Immigrants, workers, and people in heavily “red” or “blue” states deserve to feel that their voice actually counts, not that it’s canceled out by the system. A direct popular vote would push candidates to listen to all communities—including Latino and working-class neighborhoods like mine—instead of just a handful of swing states.

As someone who teaches kids every day about fairness, inclusion, and everyone’s voice mattering, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, whether you live in a big city or a rural town. Our democracy should not hinge on a few swing states, but on the collective will of all voters, including naturalized citizens and noncitizens’ families who are deeply affected by policy but often feel sidelined. If a full popular vote feels like too big a leap right away, I’d at least support reforms like proportional allocation of electors and ranked-choice voting to better reflect the true preferences of the people.

I think the Electoral College still has an important role in protecting the voice of smaller states like Missouri, so I wouldn’t support scrapping it altogether. However, I’d be open to some sensible reforms—like allocating electors by congressional district or tightening rules around faithless electors—so that people feel their votes matter more without turning our elections into a chaotic national popular vote contest.

My mom and dad say voting is how we’re fair to everybody, and I like when things are fair. I think the person who gets the most people’s votes should be the president, like how the kid with the most votes is line leader at school. If the Electoral College makes it so the winner isn’t who most people picked, I think we should change it so everyone’s vote really counts the same.

As someone who believes every person’s voice should matter equally, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that the candidate with the most votes always wins. Working in healthcare, I see how different policies affect people directly, and it bothers me that some votes effectively count more than others just because of where people live. A straightforward, popular-vote system would feel more fair, more democratic, and more in line with the values I try to live by—dignity and equal respect for every individual.

I think it’s time to move to a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts the same, whether you’re in New York, Texas, or a small town anywhere else. The current Electoral College gives too much power to a few swing states and can ignore the will of the majority, which doesn’t sit right with my sense of fairness and democracy. As a Democrat and a Catholic who cares about everyone having a voice, I want a system where candidates have to speak to all communities—including Hispanic and working-class families like mine—not just the ones that tip the Electoral College.

I don’t really understand all the details of the Electoral College, but I think it sounds more fair if every person’s vote for president counted the same no matter what state they live in. My parents say some states matter more than others in elections, and that doesn’t seem right to me, so I’d rather have a system where whoever gets the most votes from all the people wins.

I think the Electoral College should stay in place, because it forces candidates to pay attention to smaller and more rural states instead of just chasing votes in big coastal cities. That said, I’d be open to reforms like the way Maine and Nebraska do it, splitting electoral votes by congressional district, so people in every area feel like their vote matters more.

As someone who studies institutions for a living, I find the Electoral College anachronistic and normatively indefensible in a modern democracy that purports to value political equality. I would strongly support replacing it with a national popular vote—ideally through a constitutional amendment, or at least via the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact—so that each citizen’s ballot carries the same weight regardless of state boundaries. Short of that, reforms like proportional allocation of electors and ranked-choice voting at the state level could mitigate the current system’s distortions, but they are second-best solutions to a fundamentally structural problem.

I think the Electoral College needs serious reform, if not replacement, because it makes some people’s votes count more just based on what state they live in, and that doesn’t sit right with me when we have the tech to do better. A national popular vote, or at least a system that proportionally allocates electors, would make elections feel more fair and push candidates to speak to everyone, not just a few swing states. As someone who believes in using technology to improve systems, I’d like to see modern, secure voting infrastructure that makes every vote easier to cast and harder to ignore.

I’d like to see the Electoral College reformed, not scrapped. I think we should keep the state-by-state system so smaller and rural states like where I’m from don’t get steamrolled by big cities, but I’d support changes like awarding electors proportionally or by congressional district so every vote feels like it counts more. A system that encourages candidates to visit and listen to people in all parts of the country—urban, suburban, and rural—would be better for the long-term stability and fairness of our democracy.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but improved—not scrapped. It forces candidates to pay attention to different parts of the country instead of just big cities, which protects folks in places like Michigan, but I’d be open to reforms like allocating electors by congressional district or tightening rules so states follow clearer, uniform standards.
